questions.text: A G1P0 woman comes to OPD at 8 weeks of gestation with a Transvaginal USG report showing an intrauterine gestational sac with MSD 28 mm & no fetal pole/embryo. What is the most plausible diagnosis for this condition?
questions.solution:
An intrauterine gestational sac with an MSD ≥25 mm without a fetal pole or embryo is diagnostic of an early pregnancy loss (anembryonic pregnancy)/missed abortion/blighted ovum. This finding suggests the pregnancy did not develop as expected.

a. Pregnancy of unknown location

  • Incorrect: A pregnancy of unknown location (PUL) refers to a situation where a pregnancy cannot be located via ultrasound, either in the uterus or outside the uterus. In this case, there is a clear intrauterine gestational sac, so it does not fit the definition of PUL.

c. Ectopic pregnancy

  • Incorrect: An ectopic pregnancy refers to a pregnancy that implants outside the uterus. The presence of an intrauterine gestational sac makes this diagnosis unlikely.

d. Corpus luteal cyst

  • Incorrect: A corpus luteal cyst is an ovarian cyst that can form after ovulation. It is not related to the presence of an intrauterine gestational sac.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A G2P0A1 woman presents after a spontaneous abortion, 2 months back with complaints of bleeding per vaginum & lower abdominal pain. Her UPT comes out to be strongly positive & she denies having any physical intimacy with her male counterpart for past 2 months. On getting a Sonography done, ovaries show this appearance. What do you think is the most likely cause of this bleeding?
questions.solution:
The positive UPT and ovarian appearance could indicate theca lutein cysts, which are commonly associated with molar pregnancies. The absence of intimacy suggests that persistent trophoblastic tissue is producing high levels of hCG, typical of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), such as a molar pregnancy.

b. Incomplete abortion
(Incorrect): Incomplete abortion may cause bleeding, but it is less likely here given the positive UPT and ovarian findings suggestive of trophoblastic disease. Moreover, 2 months have passed since the initial abortion.

c. Uterine arteriovenous malformation
(Incorrect): While uterine arteriovenous malformation can cause abnormal bleeding, it would not explain the positive UPT or the ovarian findings seen on sonography.

d. Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia
(Incorrect): This condition may cause abnormal bleeding but is not associated with a positive pregnancy test or ovarian changes seen on ultrasound.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Theca luetin cysts are more common with a complete mole
  • Likely result from ovarian overstimulation by excessive hCG levels.
  • Remember that hCG and luteinizing hormone share the same receptor, and both can stimulate the theca layer that surrounds follicles.
  • Because theca-lutein cysts regress following pregnancy evacuation and subsequent hCG level decline, expectant management is preferred.

questions.text:
A 23 year old nulliparous woman presents to the ER with abdominal pain & vaginal bleeding. Her vitals are stable. UPT positive. A transvaginal scan is suggestive of tubal ectopic pregnancy with G-sac >3 cm. Beta HCG 6600 IU/L. Fetal cardiac activity is seen on M-mode. She also has an evidence of extensive contralateral tubal disease & wishes to preserve fertility.
Which procedure is the most suited to this clinical scenario:
questions.solution:
This procedure involves making an incision in the fallopian tube to remove the ectopic pregnancy while preserving the tube. Given the presence of extensive contralateral tubal disease, preserving fertility is crucial in this case, making laparoscopic salpingotomy the best option.

a) Laparotomy
(Incorrect): Laparotomy is usually reserved for hemodynamically unstable patients or cases with significant intra-abdominal bleeding. Since this patient is stable, a less invasive approach like laparoscopy is preferred.

b) Laparoscopic salpingectomy
(Incorrect): Salpingectomy, which involves removal of the affected fallopian tube, would decrease the chances of preserving fertility, especially with contralateral tubal disease.

d) Expectant management
(Incorrect): Expectant management is not suitable because the gestational sac is greater than 3 cm, beta-HCG is elevated, and there is fetal cardiac activity present. These are contraindications to conservative management.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  1. The best candidate for medical therapy is the woman who is asymptomatic, motivated, and compliant.
  2. With medical therapy, some classic predictors of success include a
    • low initial serum B-hCG level,<5000
    • small ectopic pregnancy size<3cm gestational sac
    • absent fetal cardiac activity.
  3. Of these, initial serum b-hCG level is the best prognostic indicator with single-dose MTX.
  4. SURGICAL MANAGEMENT IN UNRUPTURED ECTOPIC:

Family not complete: linear salpingostomy

Family complete: salpingectomy

Indications of salpingectomy:

1. Ruptured ectopic irrespective of age and parity of patient

2. Unruptered ectopic: Only if family of patient complete

3. Unruptured: if sac size >/=5cms.

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 21, Diagnosis & Management of Ectopic Pregnancy

questions.text: A 36 year old G1P0 woman, conceived via IVF after 7 years of her marriage. Her dual marker was done in the first trimester which was screen negative. At 16 weeks' gestation she is scheduled for a quadruple marker test. Which of the following is not a part of the popular "quad marker test"?
questions.solution:
The quad screen measures levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG), unconjugated estriol-3 and inhibin A in a pregnant women's blood. It's a screening test for congenital anomalies.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Inhibit A is used in screening
  • Inhibit B is tumor marker for Granulosa cell tumor
  • DUAL MARKER: HCG and PAPP-A
  • TRIPLE MARKER: HCG, AFP, Estriol.

questions.text: Fractured chromosomes in fetus are seen as a teratogenic effect of:
questions.solution:
LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) has been associated with chromosomal breakage in some experimental settings. While its exact teratogenic effects in humans remain debated, it is the most likely option associated with chromosomal abnormalities among the choices.

a. Heroin

Incorrect. Heroin is an opioid that can lead to complications such as intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), preterm birth, and neonatal abstinence syndrome,but it is not typically associated with chromosomal damage or fractures.

b. Cocaine

Incorrect. Cocaine use during pregnancy is linked to vasoconstriction, which can cause placental abruption, preterm birth, and IUGR, but it does not typically cause fractured chromosomes.

c. Marijuana

Incorrect. Although marijuana use during pregnancy can affect fetal development and lead to low birth weight or cognitive issues,it is not known to cause chromosomal fractures.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Cocaine:-Serious potential maternal complications are cerebrovascular hemorrhage, myocardial damage, and placental abruption.
  • Methamphetamine:-use in pregnancy is consistently associated with small-for-gestational age newborns, and children are at risk for developmental delays and behavioral abnormalities
  • Opioids:- NBDPS did identify a slightly greater risk for spina bifida, gastroschisis, and cardiac abnormalities with periconceptional opioid exposure Correct.

Reference: LSD and genetic damage. Science. 1971 Apr 30;172(3982):431-40.

questions.text: Most common presentation of molar pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Vaginal bleeding: Vaginal bleeding is the commonest presentation (90%) The blood may be mixed with a gelatinous fluid from ruptured cysts giving the appearance of discharge "white currant in red currant juice"

SYMPTOMS OF MOLAR PREGNANCY

  • Varying degree of lower abdominal pain may be due to

(a) over stretching of the uterus,

(b) concealed hemorrhage,

(c) rarely perforation of the uterus by the invasive mole,

(d) infection or

(e) uterine contractions to expel out the contents.

  • Constitutional symptoms:

(a) The patient becomes sick without any apparent reason.

(b) Vomiting of pregnancy becomes excessive to the stage of hyperemesis in 15% cases. It is probably related to excess chorionic gonadotropin.

(c) Breathlessness due to pulmonary embolization of the trophoblastic cells (2%).

(d) Thyrotoxic features of tremors or tachycardia are present on occasion (2%). It is probably due to increased chorionic thyrotropin.

  • Expulsion of grape-like vesicles per vaginum is diagnostic of vesicular mole.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Clinical findings in molar pregnancy:-

  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Uterine size increase more rapidly than expected
  • enlarged uterus is comparatively softer.
  • Fetal heart motion is absent with complete moles.

choices.text: Absolute values of serial beta HCG estimation

questions.text: Definitive diagnosis of a molar pregnancy is made by which of the following modalities:
questions.solution:
Definitive diagnosis is made by histological examination of the products of conception OPTION C.

The basic findings are

(1) There is marked proliferation of the syncytial and cytotrophoblastic epithelium.

(2) Marked thinning of the stromal tissue due to hydropic degeneration.

(3) There is absence of blood vessels in the villi which seems primary rather than due to pressure atrophy.

(4) The villous pattern is distinctly maintained.

DIAGNOSIS OF MOLAR PREGNANCY

  1. Sonography: Characteristic feature of molar pregnancy is "snowstorm" appearance Sometimes confusion arises with the missed abortion, partial mole or the degenerated fibroid. Doppler USG, sonography of liver, kidneys and spleen is also carried out.

  1. Quantitative estimation of chorionic gonadotropin:
  • High hCG titer in urine diluted up to 1 in 200 to 1 in 500 beyond 100 days of gestation is very much suggestive.
  • Rapidly increasing value of serum hCG (hCG > 100,000 mIU/mL),is usual with molar pregnancies. Normal pregnancy value reaches a peak at about 10-14 weeks and rarely it is more than 100,000 mIU/mL.
  • Serum hCG value greater than 2 multiples of the median (MOM)for corresponding gestational age is of value.
  1. CT and MRI: Routine use of computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging for diagnosis is not recommended.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Histopathology is best to make definitive diagnosis of molar pregnancy.

Feature on HPE:

questions.text:
A 22-year old G1P0 woman comes at 6 weeks' gestation with bleeding per vaginum. The sonography shows the following

Best method for management in this case:
questions.solution:
The image shows "snowstorm appearance" of uterus, characteristic of complete mole.

DEFINITIVE MANAGEMENT OF MOLAR PREGNANCY:

Suction evacuation (SE) is the method of treatment.

It is safe, rapid and effective in almost all cases.

Suction evacuation can safely be done even when the uterus is of 28 weeks of gestation.

a. Dilatation & curettage (D&C)

Incorrect. Although D&C is a method used in managing miscarriage, in the case of a complete mole, suction evacuation is the preferred method due to its ability to completely remove the molar tissue.

b. Dilatation alone

Incorrect. Dilatation without evacuation would be inadequate to remove the molar tissue, which can lead to complications like persistent GTD.

d. Mifepristone + Misoprostol combination

Incorrect. This combination is typically used for medical management of early miscarriage or for medical termination of pregnancy, but it is not recommended in cases of molar pregnancy due to the risk of incomplete expulsion of the molar tissue.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Regardless of uterine size, molar evacuation by suction curettage usually is the preferred treatment.
  • Intraoperative bleeding can be greater with molar pregnancy than with a comparably sized uterus containing nonmolar products. Thus with large moles, adequate anesthesia, sufficient intravenous access, and blood-banking support is imperative.

choices.text: Preparation of cervix immediately prior to uterine removal is safe
Use of oxytocin infusion prior to completion of removal is recommended
Anti-D prophylaxis is recommended following removal of a partial mole
Histological assessment of material obtained is recommended to exclude trophoblastic neoplasia if no fetal parts are identified at any stage of the pregnancy

questions.text: A 24 year old woman with molar pregnancy is scheduled for a suction curettage. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the procedure?
questions.solution:
The use of oxytocic agents (such as oxytocin) should be avoided before the complete removal of molar tissue as it may increase the risk of uterine contraction and trapping of remaining molar tissue, leading to incomplete evacuation. Oxytocics are typically used after the evacuation is complete to promote uterine contraction and reduce bleeding.

OPTION a: Preparation of cervix immediately prior to uterine removal is safe
Correct. Cervical preparation with medications like misoprostol or mechanical dilators is often used to reduce the risk of cervical trauma during the procedure. This is considered a safe practice prior to uterine evacuation.

OPTION c: Anti-D prophylaxis is recommended following removal of a partial mole
Correct. In Rh-negative women, anti-D prophylaxis is recommended after evacuation of a partial mole to prevent Rh sensitization, similar to other obstetric procedures where fetal-maternal hemorrhage might occur.

OPTION d: Histological assessment of material obtained is recommended to exclude trophoblastic neoplasia if no fetal parts are identified at any stage of the pregnancy

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Management of Hydatidiform mole


FOLLOW UP AFTER SURGEY: Beta hcg weekly till 3 consecutive findings are normal(undetectable),then monthly till 6months.

Pregnancy contraindicated till 6 months(Contraceptive of choice: OCPS)

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 38, Management of Gestational Trophoblastic Disease

choices.text: No need to defer conception as the chemotherapeutic agents used are neither gametotoxic nor teratogenic

questions.text: Women who undergo chemotherapy for GTN should defer conception for:
questions.solution:
• Women with GTN who have successfully completed chemotherapy are advised to delay pregnancy for 1 year

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Women with GTN who have successfully completed chemotherapy are advised to delay pregnancy or 1 year.
  • Most relapses develop within this time period
  • Also, methotrexate may persist in human tissues or months
  • Despite this, women who become pregnant within 1 year post chemotherapy or GN can be reassured of a likely favorable outcome

questions.text: Pathological features consistent with diagnosis of complete molar pregnancy do not include:
questions.solution:
P57 is paternally imprinted and maternally expressed gene.

Complete mole do not have maternal genetic material.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Difference between complete and partial mole


Tips & Tricks

Remember: "P" for "P" - Partial mole has positive P57 kip2 immunostaining

questions.text: Diagnostic tool of choice for tubal ectopic pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Transvaginal ultrasound is the diagnostic tool of choice for tubal ectopic pregnancy.

On transvaginal imaging, findings indicating definitive diagnosis of a tubal ectopic pregnancy include:

  • extraovarian adnexal mass comprising a gestational sac containing a yolk sac
  • extraovarian adnexal mass comprising a gestational sac and fetal pole (with or without cardiac activity)

On transvaginal imaging, findings indicating a high probabilityof a tubal ectopic pregnancy include:

  • extraovarian adnexal mass with an empty gestational sac (tubal ring sign or bagel sign)
  • extraovarian heterogeneous adnexal mass (blob sign)

On transvaginal imaging, findings indicating possible tubal ectopic pregnancy include:

  • empty uterus
  • fluid within the uterine cavity (pseudosac)

The clinical presentation, serum hCG levels, uterine, and adnexal findings must be considered together.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Transvaginal ultrasound is the diagnostic tool of choice for tubal ectopic pregnancy.
  • Showing empty uterus, pseudo gestational sac, extra ovarian adnexal mass
  • Ring of fire, Bagel sign

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 21, Diagnosis & Management of Ectopic Pregnancy

choices.text: A gestational sac is present below the level of internal cervical os

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the ultrasound criteria for diagnosis of a cervical ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Cervical ectopic pregnancy is the rarest form of ectopic pregnancy, accounting for less than 1% of these cases.
  • The most common presenting symptom of cervical pregnancy is painless vaginal bleeding.
  • Cervical pregnancy can also be widely misdiagnosed as an ongoing abortion.
  • The best way to distinguish the two situations is by the sliding sign, which means that when gentle pressure is applied on the cervix with the probe, the implanted cervical pregnancy does not slide, unlike the gestational sac of the abortion.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Criteria for cervical pregnancy


Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 21, Diagnosis & Management of Ectopic Pregnancy

choices.text: G sac located laterally in the intramural part of fallopian tube

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the ultrasound criteria for diagnosis of an interstitial ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The presence of the "interstitial line sign" is actually a key diagnostic feature for interstitial ectopic pregnancy. It refers to an echogenic line extending from the endometrium to the interstitial sac, indicating the abnormal location of the gestational sac.

b. Empty uterine cavity

Correct. An empty uterine cavity is often seen in interstitial ectopic pregnancies, as the pregnancy is located in the interstitial (cornual) part of the fallopian tube, not within the uterine cavity.

c. Presence of myometrial mantle sign

Correct. The myometrial mantle sign refers to a thin layer of myometrium (<5 mm) surrounding the gestational sac, which is another feature suggestive of interstitial ectopic pregnancy.

d. G sac located laterally in the intramural part of fallopian tube

Correct. In interstitial ectopic pregnancies, the gestational sac is often located in the lateral intramural part of the fallopian tube, at the junction where the tube passes through the muscular uterine wall.

KEY TAKE AWAY:


Criteria for interstitial ectopic

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 21, Diagnosis & Management of Ectopic Pregnancy

questions.text: Expectant management is an option for clinically stable women with an ultrasound diagnosis of tubal ectopic pregnancy & a decreasing beta hCG level, initially less than ____ IU/L:
questions.solution:
• Expectant management is a reasonable option for appropriately selected and counselled women. They must be willing and able to attend for follow-up, have minimal pain, and have low or declining serum β-hCG levels.
  • Selection criteria for expectant management were clinical stability with no abdominal pain, no evidence of significant haemoperitoneum on ultrasound scan, an ectopic pregnancy measuring less than 30mm in mean diameter with no evidence of embryonic cardiac activity, a serum β-hCG level of less than 1500IU/L and the woman's consent.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Criteria for medical management of tubal ectopic pregnancies

questions.text: Hyperemesis gravidarum can be diagnosed when there is protracted NVP with the triad of dehydration, electrolyte imbalance & more than what percentage of pre-pregnancy weight loss:
questions.solution:
Hyperemesis gravidarum is diagnosed when a pregnant woman experiences severe nausea and vomiting (NVP) that leads to:

  • Dehydration
  • Electrolyte imbalance
  • More than 5% of pre-pregnancy weight loss

This condition may require medical intervention to manage the symptoms and ensure the health of both the mother and the fetus.

KEY TAKE AWAY:


Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 69, The Management of Nausea and Vomiting of Pregnancy and Hyperemesis Gravidarum

questions.text: A 28 year old primigravida comes to ER with severe protracted nausea & vomiting. Her lips are chapped, she has decreased urine output too. IV fluid of choice for rehydration in this case:
questions.solution:
Normal saline with additional KCl: This option is ideal as it helps rehydrate the patient while also addressing potential potassium depletion due to vomiting,

In cases of severe nausea and vomiting, particularly with signs of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance, the choice of IV fluid is crucial. Here's a breakdown of the options:

  • Ringer lactate: Good for general fluid resuscitation but may not provide enough chloride.
  • Isolyte M: An isotonic solution that can be used but may not be the first choice in this scenario.
  • Dextrose 10%: Primarily provides carbohydrates and may not address electrolyte imbalances effectively.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Fluid of choice is NS with KCl to correct dehydration along with electrolyte imbalances.


Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 69, The Management of Nausea and Vomiting of Pregnancy and Hyperemesis Gravidarum

questions.text: A woman in the early first trimester of pregnancy presents for evaluation of vaginal bleeding. You order a β-hCG test. Over what time period would you expect the β-hCG level to approximately double in case of a normal healthy intrauterine pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• One wouldexpect the β-hCG level to double within 48-72 h during the first 12 weeks of pregnancy (Kadar's rule).
  • This yardstick has become of importance in identifying cases of possible poor pregnancy outcome (for example, early miscarriage, ectopic pregnancy) where hCG levels don't double up in the requisite time.

KEY TAKE AWAY:


Critical titre of HCG

TVS:2000 IU

TAS:6500 IU

questions.text: The sensitivity of a urine pregnancy test is:
questions.solution:
• hCG is secreted by syncytiotrophoblasts.
  • False positive or negative results in terms of pregnancy detection are possible but exceedingly rare.
  • With modern laboratory assays, detection levels of serum b-hCG are as low as 5 IU/L.
  • The sensitivity of a urine pregnancy test is about 25 IU/L(OPTION C) .
  • The typical level in a healthy pregnancy on the day of the missed period is 50 to 100 IU/L.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • hCG is secreted by syncytiotrophoblasts.
  • The sensitivity of a urine pregnancy test is about 25 IU/L

choices.text: More prevalent in hydatidiform mole and multiple pregnancy
Pregnancy-Unique Quantification of Emesis (PUQE) score can be used to classify the severity
It is associated with hyponatraemia & hyperkalaemia

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding hyperemesis gravidarum, except:
questions.solution:
HYPEREMESIS GRAVIDARUM - RISK FACTORS

(1) It is mostly limited to the first trimester

(2) It is more common in first pregnancy, with a tendency to recur again in subsequent pregnancies

(3) Younger age

(4) Low body mass

(5) History of motion sickness or migraine

(6) It has got a familial history - mother and sisters also suffer from the same manifestation

(7) It is more prevalent in hydatidiform mole and multiple pregnancy

An objective and validated index of nausea and vomiting such as the Pregnancy-Unique Quantification of Emesis (PUQE) score can be used to classify the severity of hyperemesis gravidarum.

NVP and HG are associated with hyponatremia, hypokalemia, low serum urea, raised haematocrit and ketonuria with a metabolic hypochloremic alkalosis. If severe, a metabolic acidosis may develop.

KEY TAKE AWAY:


Reference: COG Green Top Guideline no. 69, The Management of Nausea and Vomiting of Pregnancy and Hyperemesis Gravidarum

questions.text: Which uterine anomaly most commonly leads to recurrent pregnancy loss?
questions.solution:
This is the most common uterine anomaly associated with recurrent pregnancy loss. It is characterized by a fibrous or muscular septum dividing the uterine cavity, which can interfere with implantation and lead to miscarriages.

b. Bicornuate uterus: This anomaly can also contribute to pregnancy complications but is less frequently associated with recurrent pregnancy loss compared to a septate uterus.

c. Unicornuate uterus: While this can lead to pregnancy complications and loss, it is not as commonly associated with recurrent pregnancy loss as a septate uterus.

d. Uterus didelphys: This anomaly has a separate cervix and often leads to less frequent miscarriages,though it may pose other risks during pregnancy.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Overall, the septate uterus is the most significant in terms of recurrent pregnancy loss

questions.text: A 32 year old with history of 3 abortions in the past 2 years is diagnosed with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. What is the treatment of choice in subsequent pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Aspirin & heparin form the cornerstone of management of APLA syndrome.
  • For women who fulfil the laboratory criteria of APS and a history of three or more pregnancy losses, we suggest administration with low-dose aspirin (75 to 100 mg/day) starting before conception, and a prophylactic dose heparin (Unfractionated heparin [UFH]or Low molecular weight heparin [LMWH]) starting at date of a positive pregnancy test.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

choices.text: Mifepristone 600 mg orally followed by misoprostol 800 μg vaginally 7 days later
Mifepristone 600 mg orally followed by misoprostol 800 μg orally 48 hours later
Mifepristone 200 mg orally followed by misoprostol 800 μg buccally 24 hours later
Misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally 3 doses 3 hours apart

questions.text: A 21 year old woman presents with a positive urine pregnancy test at 6 weeks of gestation. She doesn't wish to continue the pregnancy & seeks medical termination. Which of the following regimens is most appropriate in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
• Because of its greater efficacy, mifepristone plus misoprostol combinations are favored for medical termination of pregnancy.
  • For gestations ≤70 days, the most widely accepted regimen is mifepristone, 200 mg given orally on day 0.
  • This is followed in 24 to 48 hours by an 800-μg misoprostol dose that is administered vaginally/ buccally/ sublingually(American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, 2020).

KEY TAKE AWAY:


Other methods for second trimester MTP:

  • Extra amniotic ethacridine
  • Intra amniotic NS instillation
  • Dilatation and evacuation: Done using ovum/sponge holding forceps.

questions.text: A 28-year old G3P0A2, presents to the ER at nine weeks of gestation. She complains of vaginal bleed, for the last 48 hours. She had a positive pregnancy test five weeks ago. The ultrasound reveals an empty gestational sac. Which of the following is the most possible reason for this?
questions.solution:
Aneuploidy, which refers to an abnormal number of chromosomes, is one of the most common causes of early pregnancy loss. The ultrasound finding of an empty gestational sac, also known as a "blighted ovum" or anembryonic pregnancy, often points to chromosomal abnormalities like aneuploidy, where the embryo fails to develop properly.

OPTION a: Cervical insufficiency: This is usually associated with second-trimester pregnancy loss or preterm delivery rather than first-trimester losses.

OPTION c: APLA (Antiphospholipid Antibody) syndrome: This autoimmune condition is linked with recurrent pregnancy loss, but it typically causes miscarriages later in pregnancy  than the early losses seen with aneuploidy.

OPTION d: Septate uterus: While a septate uterus can lead to recurrent pregnancy loss, it is typically related to structural implantation issues and doesn't directly cause the findings of an empty gestational sac seen in this scenario.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  1. Most common aneuploidy are
  • trisomy, found in 50 to 60 percent;
  • monosomy X, in 9 to 13 percent;
  • triploidy, in 11 to 12 percent
  1. Monosomy X (45,X) is the single most frequent specific chromosomal abnormality

questions.text: A 32 year old G3P0A2 woman has experienced two second trimester pregnancy losses. Which of the following imaging modalities is the best to ascertain a uterine anomaly?
questions.solution:
OPTION C: The preferred technique to evaluate the uterus is transvaginal 3D ultrasound (US), which has a high sensitivity and specificity, and can distinguish between septate uterus and bicornuate uterus with normal cervix.

  • Sonohysterography (SHG) OPTION B is more accurate than hysterosalpingography (HSG) OPTION A in diagnosing uterine malformations. It can be used to evaluate uterine morphology when 3D ultrasound (US) is not available, or when tubal patency has to be investigated.
  • MRI is not recommended as first line optionfor the assessment of uterine malformations in women with RPL but can be used where 3D US is not available.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • The diagnostic accuracy of 3-D USG approaches 97 percent.
  • Thus, coronal images can be constructed, and these are essential in evaluating both internal and external uterine contours.
  • Both 2-D and 3-D USG are suitable for use in pregnancy

Reference: ESHRE guidelines on recurrent pregnancy loss

choices.text: Any of the above may be used

questions.text: A couple seeks genetic counselling for consecutive 3 first trimester pregnancy loss. The gynaecologist counselled them regarding genetic testing of products of conception (POCs). Which is the best method to do so out of the following available options?
questions.solution:
• It is possible to ascertain whether an early pregnancy loss is due to a genetically abnormal embryo or fetus (aneuploidy) by analysing the pregnancy or fetal tissue.
  • Analysis by conventional karyotyping is limited by the failure of tissue cultureand the fact that it does not distinguish between maternal contamination and a normal (euploid) female fetus.
  • FISH is limited as it only uses probes for certain chromosomes, and therefore does not necessarily detect the chromosomal cause of the miscarriage.
  • New techniques such as next generation sequencing (NGS), SNP arrays, whole genome screening (WGS) and whole exome screening (WES) have not yet been extensively investigated in genetic analysis of pregnancy tissue following pregnancy loss but may be useful in the near future.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Array CGH is a better technique, and currently preferred technique, looking at all chromosomes and avoiding the limitations associated with karyotype and FISH, but may identify clinically irrelevant findings.

Reference: ESHRE guidelines on recurrent pregnancy loss

questions.text: Which of the following ectopic pregnancies is the earliest to rupture?
questions.solution:
The isthmic part of the fallopian tube is the narrowest segment, so an ectopic pregnancy located here is under the greatest pressure as the embryo grows. Due to the limited space, an isthmic ectopic pregnancy tends to rupture earlier, usually between 6-8 weeks of gestation.

OPTION a: Ampullary: The ampullary portion of the tube is the most common site for ectopic pregnancies but has a wider diameter compared to the isthmus, so it tends to rupture later than an isthmic ectopic pregnancy.

OPTION c: Interstitial: Interstitial ectopic pregnancies occur in the part of the tube that passes through the muscular wall of the uterus. These can expand more due to the surrounding myometrium, so they usually rupture later, often around 10-12 weeks. So, it is the site where ectopic pregnancy lasts for longer duration and hence it is the most dangerous site for ectopic.

OPTION d: Fimbrial: Fimbrial ectopic pregnancies occur in the portion of the tube closest to the ovary and have more space for growth before rupture, making them less likely to rupture early.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

As the isthmic portion is narrow and the wall is less distensible, the wall may be easily eroded by the chorionic villi. Isthmic rupture usually occurs at 6-8 weeks, the ampullary one at 8-12 weeks and the interstitial one at about 4 months.

questions.text: Commonest karyotype seen in cases of complete mole:
questions.solution:
In general, complete moles have a 46XX karyotype (85%), the molar chromosomes are derived entirely from the father. The ovum nucleus may be either absent (empty ovum) or inactivated which has been fertilized by a haploid sperm. It then duplicates its own chromosomes after meiosis. This phenomenon is known as androgenesis. Infrequently, the chromosomal pattern may be 46XY or 45X.

b. 46 XY: A small proportion of complete moles can have a 46 XY karyotype, which occurs when two sperm fertilize an empty ovum. However, this is much less common than 46 XX.

c. 69 XXY: This karyotype is seen in partial moles, where a triploid complement is present due to fertilization of an ovum by two sperm or by a diploid sperm. It is not typical for a complete mole.

d. 45 XO: This karyotype is associated with Turner syndrome and has no relation to molar pregnancies.

Thus, 46 XX is the most common karyotype seen in cases of complete mole.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: A 24 year old woman, diagnosed with complete molar pregnancy was taken up for suction & evacuation. Oxytocin infusion was started prior to evacuation by the junior resident. She developed symptoms of acute chest pain, tachycardia, tachypnea and dyspnea about 4-6 hours following evacuation. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Acute pulmonary insufficiency due to pulmonary embolization of the trophoblastic cells is most likely in this case.
  • Symptoms of acute chest pain, tachycardia, tachypnea and dyspnea develop about 4-6 hours following evacuation.
  • Medical induction (oxytocin infusion) before evacuation may increase the risk of pulmonary insufficiency (RCOG).
  • Arterial PO2 is monitored.
  • Patient may need ventilatory assistance and intensive care unit management

In the context of molar pregnancy and suction evacuation, acute pulmonary insufficiency or acute pulmonary edema is a well-recognized complication that can occur, especially when oxytocin infusion is started early. The possible mechanisms include:

  • Trophoblastic embolization: In cases of molar pregnancy, trophoblastic tissue can enter the bloodstream during uterine evacuation, leading to pulmonary emboli.
  • Fluid overload: Excessive fluid administration, in combination with oxytocin, can result in pulmonary edema due to fluid retention and overload.
  • Oxytocin-related complications: Oxytocin has antidiuretic effects, which can contribute to fluid retention and subsequently lead to pulmonary edema.

Incorrect options:

  • Myocardial infarction: Less likely in a young woman without predisposing factors for ischemic heart disease.
  • Post-op atelectasis: This can occur but typically presents as mild respiratory distress without the acute onset of severe symptoms like chest pain and dyspnea.
  • Cardiac tamponade: Unlikely without associated trauma or fluid accumulation around the heart; symptoms are more related to hypotension and muffled heart sounds.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

The symptoms of acute pulmonary insufficiency include acute chest pain, tachycardia, tachypnea, dyspnea, and in severe cases, frothy sputum and cyanosis

questions.text: A 30 year old woman with complete molar pregnancy underwent suction & evacuation. Which of the following contraceptive methods is contraindicated in this case?
questions.solution:
Contraindicated due to the potential risk of infection or perforation in a uterus that is still healing after evacuation. Additionally, in cases where GTN develops, the IUD could complicate further management or obscure signs of a problem.

Use of contraception post molar pregnancy:

  • IUD is contraindicated, because of its frequent association of irregular bleeding-a feature often coexists with choriocarcinoma.
  • Combined oral pills can be used after the hCG value has become normal.
  • Injection DMPA can be used safely.
  • Barrier method of contraception can also be used.
  • Surgical sterilization is another alternative when she has completed her family.

OPTIONWISE EXPLANATION:

After the evacuation of a complete molar pregnancy, it is essential to avoid pregnancy during the follow-up period to monitor for gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) by tracking β-hCG levels. Certain contraceptive methods are preferred over others:

  1. DMPA injection (Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate): Safe and often recommended because it is highly effective and doesn't interfere with β-hCG monitoring.
  2. Combined OC pills: Safeand often used for contraception post-molar pregnancy. They help regulate cycles and prevent pregnancy during the follow-up period.

Thus, IUDs are contraindicated after a molar pregnancy due to the risks associated with uterine healing and possible infection.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Contraceptive of choice after molar pregnancy is COCs started after HCG becomes normal.
  • IUD is contraindicated due to risk of uterine perforation.
  • Most recommend combination hormonal contraception, inject-able depot medroxyprogesterone acetate, or progestin implant
